active_learning.discussion_prompt: In a group discussion, debate the optimal M-of-N configuration (e.g., 2-of-3 vs. 3-of-5) for a financial institution's PKI key recovery process. Consider trade-offs in security, accessibility, and compliance with NIST SP 800-57. Support arguments with real-world examples like HSM-based recoveries and address common misconceptions, such as partial shares revealing key information.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

distractor_protocol.step: Identify common misconceptions about the topic
Ensure distractors are similar in length and complexity
Include partial truths that require deeper understanding

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in Cryptography and PKI. Generate 30 high-quality MCQ flashcards on 'M-of-N Key Split Mechanisms' (Topic Hierarchy: Cybersecurity > 001_Cryptography > 009_Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) > 006_Key Management > Key 010_Backup and 005_Recovery > M-of-N Key Split Mechanisms). Use this research context: M-of-N divides secret into N shares, any M reconstructs (e.g., Shamir's SSS via polynomial interpolation); enhances PKI resilience per NIST SP 800-57 (key mgmt) and NISTIR 8214A (threshold criteria). Examples: 2-of-3 HSMs. Misconceptions: <M shares leak info. Incorporate: - Learning Objectives: [paste full list above] - Scaffolding: Distribute 7-8 cards per layer [paste scaffolding summaries]. - Active Learning: Hook each card back to one activity. - Prior/Big Picture: Resilient key backup; links to secret sharing basics. Follow Flashcard Schema exactly: Output ONLY a JSON array of 30 objects, each with 'front' (question + 4 options A-D, A correct), 'back' (correct_answer, explanation w/ source/Bloom/layer, active_learning_hook, scaffolding_layer). Ensure distractors per protocol. Cards must be university-level, active recall-focused, no hints in questions.
